questions.text: Identify the nerve passing around the marked structure :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Common Peroneal Nerve Structure marked is the neck of fibula , a common peroneal nerve passes around it. Common Peroneal nerve The most common presentation with common peroneal nerve injury or palsy is acute foot drop.

Highyeild:

The common peroneal nerve is the smaller and terminal branch of the sciatic nerve which is composed of the posterior divisions of L4, 5, S1, 2. It courses along the upper lateral side of the popliteal fossa, deep to biceps femoris and its tendon until it gets to the posterior part of the head of the fibula. It passes forwards around the neck of the fibula within the substance of fibularis (peroneus) longus, where it terminates by dividing into the superficial and deep fibular (peroneal) nerves.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Femoral nerve is a mixed nerve of the lower limb that innervates the muscles and skin of the hip and thigh. The femoral nerve originates from the lumbar plexus The femoral nerve is split by the lateral circumflex femoral artery into an anterior and posterior division. Option: C. Sural nerve has its origins within the sciatic nerve, coming from terminal branches of the tibial and common fibular nerves Directly innervates the skin over the posterolateral aspect of the distal third of the leg. Option: D. Tibial nerve Tibial nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve, and arises at the apex of the popliteal fossa. It travels through the popliteal fossa, giving off branches to muscles in the superficial posterior compartment of the leg. The tibial nerve continues its course down the leg, posterior to the tibia. During its descent, it supplies the deep muscles of the posterior leg.

Extraedge:

The Common peroneal nerve can be palpated behind the head of the fibula and as it winds around the neck of the fibula. The common fibular (peroneal) nerve gives articular branches to the knee and superior tibiofibular joint. The lateral cutaneous nerve of the calf supplies the posterolateral side of the proximal two-thirds of the leg. It usually arises in common with the fibular (peroneal) communicating branch which joins the sural nerve in the middle third of the leg.

questions.text: Incorrect match about the pharyngeal arch artery derivative? 1 st arch- maxillary artery 2 nd arch- hyoid and stapedial artery 3 rd arch- common carotid and proximal part of ICA 4 th arch- right subclavian artery 6 th arch- Aorta on the left side Choose the correct answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 The proximal part of the sixth right arch persists as the proximal part of the right pulmonary artery while the distal section degenerates; The sixth left arch gives off the left pulmonary artery and forms the ductus arteriosus ; this duct remains pervious during the whole of fetal life, but then closes within the first few days after birth due to increased O 2 concentration. Oxygen concentration causes the production of bradykinin which causes the ductus to constrict, occluding all flow. Within 1–3 months, the ductus is obliterated and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

Highyeild:

Ortic arch vascular derivatives Aortic arch Adult derivative First ● Part of maxillary artery Second ● Hyoid artery ● Stapedial artery Third ● Common carotid artery ● Proximal internal carotid artery Fourth ● On left → aortic arch aortic arch ● On right → proximal right subclavian artery Sixth ● Proximal pulmonary arteries ● On left → ductus arteriosus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. 4 & 5 Option B. 3 & 5 Option D. 2 & 3 Option A, B and D are correct matches.

Extraedge:

Aberrant subclavian artery ; with regression of the right aortic arch 4 and the right dorsal aorta, the right subclavian artery has an abnormal origin on the left side, just below the left subclavian artery. To supply blood to the right arm, this forces the right subclavian artery to cross the midline behind the trachea and esophagus, which may constrict these organs, although usually with no clinical symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the muscles make the pelvic diaphragm? Deep Transverse Perinei Pubococcygeus Iliococcygeus Obturator Internus Choose the correct options from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

b, c Levator ani muscle is a complex unit that consists of 3 muscle components: Pubococcygeus Pubovaginalis Pub Perinealis Puboanalis Puborectalis Iliococcygeus Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction. Major function of the levator ani muscle is supporting and raising the pelvic visceral structures. It also helps in proper sexual functioning, defecation, urination, and allowing various structures to pass through it

Highyeild:

Delancey's levels of support of genital organs Levels of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage Level 1 Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendineus fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the fascia overlying the levator ani muscle. Cystocele Rectocele Level 3 Urogenital diaphragm and perineal body provide support to lower part of vagina Urethrocele Gaping introitus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B. a, b, c, d OPTION C. a, b, d OPTION D. a and d The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani. The deep transverse perineal muscle is the content of the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body.

questions.text: A hyperkinetic involuntary movement disorder characterized by intermittent, sudden, violent, involuntary, flinging, or ballistic high amplitude movements of upper limb, known as hemiballismus is due to which part involvement:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subthalamic Nucleus Hemiballismus is a hyperkinetic involuntary movement disorder characterized by intermittent, sudden, violent, involuntary, flinging, or ballistic high amplitude movements involving the ipsilateral arm and leg caused by dysfunction in the central nervous system of the contralateral side. Hemiballismus is usually caused by a stroke that affects a small area just below the basal ganglia called the subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nucleus helps control voluntary movements.

Highyeild:

Lesion in globus pallidus - athetosis Lesion in the subthalamic nucleus -hemiballismus Multiple small lesions in putamen-s. chorea Lesion in caudate nucleus- Huntington's chorea Lesion in substantia nigra -Parkinson’s disease

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Putamen Lesions in the putamen can also reduce GPi discharge and enhance the response of thalamocortical neurons, and can lead to delayed onset movement disorders such as tremor and dystonia. Option B. Globus Pallidus Lesion in globus pallidus - athetosis Option C. Substantia Nigra Lesion in substantia nigra -Parkinson’s disease

Extraedge:

Parkinson's disease is a brain disorder that causes unintended or uncontrollable movements, such as shaking, stiffness, and difficulty with balance and coordination. Symptoms usually begin gradually and worsen over time. As the disease progresses, people may have difficulty walking and talking.

questions.text: Which are the cells present in molecular layer of cerebellum: Purkinje Cells Granular Cells Basket Cells Stellate Cells Choose the correct answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3,4 Molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex contains stellate cells and basket cells .

Highyeild:

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are: Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells . They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining. Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contains flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells . Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei. Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells . It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. Cerebellar cortex cells

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A. 1,2 OPTION B. 1,3 OPTION C. 2,4 Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contains flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells . Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells .

Extraedge:

Three predominantly cerebellar symptoms: tremor, nystagmus and scanning speech

questions.text: Actions of the muscle attached to the marked area of the bone?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extension and Lateral rotation The marked area is Gluteal Tuberosity The muscle inserted to the gluteal tuberosity is Gluteus maximus Action of gluteus maximus is extension and lateral rotation of the hip.

Highyeild:

Gluteus maximus Origin Lateroposterior surface of sacrum and coccyx, gluteal surface of ilium (behind posterior gluteal line), thoracolumbar fascia, Sacrotuberous ligament Insertion Iliotibial tract, gluteal tuberosity of femur Action Hip joint: Thigh extension, thigh external rotation and assists in rising from a sitting position Innervation Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2) Arterial Supply Inferior gluteal and superior gluteal arteries

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A. Abduction and External rotation OPTION C. Extension, adduction and Lateral rotation OPTION D. Flexion and abduction The marked area is Gluteal Tuberosity The muscle inserted to the gluteal tuberosity is Gluteus maximus Action of gluteus maximus is extension and lateral rotation of the hip, therefore option A, C and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

Three bursae are usually found in relation with the deep surface of Gluteus maximus muscle: One of these, of large size, separates it from the greater trochanter; a second (often missing) is situated on the tuberosity of the ischium; a third is found between the tendon of the muscle and that of the vastus lateralis.

questions.text: Identify the marked Foramen in this butterfly shaped bone?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Foramen Rotundum The bone shown in the image is sphenoid bone and the marked structure is Foramen Rotundum .

Highyeild:

The floor of middle cranial fossa is formed by a greater wing of sphenoid and body of sphenoid. Lesser wing along with the frontal bone forms the roof of the orbit. The greater wing has 3 main openings: foramen rotundum, foramen ovale & foramen spinosum. Openings: Vidian canal is also called pterygoid canal , it contains vidian nerve ,artery and vein. Foramen spinosum contains: Middle meningeal artery Middle meningeal vein Meningeal branch of CN V3 Foramen rotundum allows the passage of the maxillary nerve (V2) , a branch of the trigeminal nerve. It also allows the passage of the artery of the foramen rotundum and an emissary vein .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B. Foramen Ovale The foramen ovale is a hole in the posterior part of the sphenoid bone, posterolateral to the foramen rotundum. It is one of the larger of the several holes (the foramina) in the skull. It transmits the mandibular nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve. OPTION C. Vidian Canal The pterygoid canal (also vidian canal) is a passage in the skull leading from just anterior to the foramen lacerum in the middle cranial fossa to the pterygopalatine fossa. The pterygoid canal runs through the base of the pterygoid process of the sphenoid bone to the back wall of the pterygopalatine fossa. OPTION D. Foramen Spinosum The foramen spinosum is located in the posteromedial part of the greater wing of sphenoid bone posterolateral to foramen ovale which connects the middle cranial fossa with the infratemporal fossa. It transmits the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein, and (usually) the nervus spinosus.

Extraedge:

The foramen lacerum is a triangular hole in the base of the skull. It is located between the sphenoid bone, the apex of the petrous part of the temporal bone, and the basilar part of the occipital bone. The two nerves that pass from the foramen lacerum are the greater petrosal nerve, which represents the pre-ganglionic parasympathetic fibers, and the deep petrosal nerve which represents the post-ganglionic sympathetic fibers.
